articles.headline: Not All Certificates of Deposit Are Plain Vanilla — or Safe
articles.snippet: A scandal involving securities that were called C.D.’s suggests that even these conservative investments warrant a close look.
articles.abstract: A scandal involving securities that were called C.D.’s suggests that even these conservative investments warrant a close look.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was bad enough when big banks started going under. Then, money market funds became suspect. But now, even the humble certificate of deposit has become mired in scandal.

articles.headline: ‘Buy America’ in Stimulus (but Good Luck With That)
articles.snippet: The idea of the clause is to rev up the American economy, but the stimulus bill is full of exceptions, allowing many imports.
articles.abstract: The idea of the clause is to rev up the American economy, but the stimulus bill is full of exceptions, allowing many imports.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “Buy America” clause in the $787 billion stimulus package signed into law on Tuesday has a certain quaintness to it. Far more than in the past, the phrase has come to mean “Buy America  if it is still made here.”

articles.headline: Netanyahu, Once Hawkish, Now Touts Pragmatism
articles.snippet: Benjamin Netanyahu, picked to lead Israel, called on the centrists and the left to form a unity government.
articles.abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu, picked to lead Israel, called on the centrists and the left to form a unity government.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Benjamin Netanyahu, the Likud Party leader chosen Friday to form Israel’s next government, likes to tell a story about his meeting last summer in Jerusalem with President Obama, who was then still the Democratic candidate.

articles.headline: Growing Worry on Rescue Takes a Toll on Banks
articles.snippet: Fears of nationalization and of Washington’s ever-changing plans for the nation’s beleaguered banks have sapped investor confidence in the industry.
articles.abstract: Fears of nationalization and of Washington’s ever-changing plans for the nation’s beleaguered banks have sapped investor confidence in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again, investors are losing confidence in the nation’s beleaguered banks — and, this time, experts say, in Washington’s ever-changing plans to rescue the banks as well.

articles.headline: First, Let’s Fix the Bonuses
articles.snippet: Financial incentives that once fostered loyalty to Wall Street firms now turn employees into greedy free agents.
articles.abstract: Financial incentives that once fostered loyalty to Wall Street firms now turn employees into greedy free agents.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If you weren’t getting a bonus, what would you not do? Would you take longer lunches, or leave early on Wednesday?”

articles.headline: Madoff Never Made Supposed Investments
articles.snippet: A report raises the question of how fake statements were generated in the absence of any genuine trading.
articles.abstract: A report raises the question of how fake statements were generated in the absence of any genuine trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: The clients who trusted Bernard L. Madoff still do not know exactly what he did with their money. But they know what he did not do with it: He did not buy any of those blue-chip stocks and Treasury bills listed on their account statements over the last 13 years.

articles.headline: More Customers Give Up the Cellphone Contract
articles.snippet: Subscription cellphone services are losing favor to pay-as-you-go plans as consumers try to cut their expenses.
articles.abstract: Subscription cellphone services are losing favor to pay-as-you-go plans as consumers try to cut their expenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe Tony Soprano was onto something. As the lead mobster in the HBO series “The Sopranos,” he and his crew often turned to prepaid cellphones, presumably to avoid wiretaps.

articles.headline: Fraud Case Shakes a Billionaire’s Caribbean Realm
articles.snippet: The story of Robert Allen Stanford’s rise is intimately linked to his foray on the island of Antigua.
articles.abstract: The story of Robert Allen Stanford’s rise is intimately linked to his foray on the island of Antigua.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Clifford Krauss, Julie Creswell and Charlie Savage.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss, Julie Creswell and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Endowment Director Is on Harvard’s Hot Seat
articles.snippet: With its endowment suffering its worst loss in 40 years, Harvard is scrambling to pay its short-term bills.
articles.abstract: With its endowment suffering its worst loss in 40 years, Harvard is scrambling to pay its short-term bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harvard may be the nation’s wealthiest university, but it is short on cash.

articles.headline: Drought Adds to Hardships in California
articles.snippet: In the Central Valley, the nation’s biggest agricultural engine, the economic downturn is being deepened by drought.
articles.abstract: In the Central Valley, the nation’s biggest agricultural engine, the economic downturn is being deepened by drought.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENDOTA, Calif.  The country’s biggest agricultural engine, California’s sprawling Central Valley, is being battered by the recession like farmland most everywhere. But in an unlucky strike of nature, the downturn is being deepened by a severe drought that threatens to drive up joblessness, increase food prices and cripple farms and towns.

articles.headline: Hold the Eulogies, Kennedy Says
articles.snippet: As he endures grueling cancer treatments, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is intent on racing time rather than looking back.
articles.abstract: As he endures grueling cancer treatments, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is intent on racing time rather than looking back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After the president of Harvard hailed him as a “national leader but a local servant,” after the pastor read the “Let us now praise famous men” passage from the Bible and after the cellist Yo-Yo Ma honored him by performing a Gershwin prelude, Senator Edward M. Kennedy lumbered across the antique stage.

articles.headline: When Consumers Cut Back: An Object Lesson From Japan
articles.snippet: Japan offers a peek at how thrift can take lasting hold of a consumer society, to disastrous effect.
articles.abstract: Japan offers a peek at how thrift can take lasting hold of a consumer society, to disastrous effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As recession-wary Americans adapt to a new frugality, Japan offers a peek at how thrift can take lasting hold of a consumer society, to disastrous effect.

articles.headline: Obama Planning to Slash Deficit, Despite Stimulus Spending
articles.snippet: President Obama will set a goal this week to cut the annual deficit at least in half by the end of his term, according to officials.
articles.abstract: President Obama will set a goal this week to cut the annual deficit at least in half by the end of his term, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After a string of costly bailout and stimulus measures, President Obama will set a goal this week to cut the annual deficit at least in half by the end of his term, administration officials said. The reduction would come in large part through Iraq troop withdrawals and higher taxes on the wealthy.

articles.headline: After Huge Losses, a Move to Reclaim Executives’ Pay
articles.snippet: A growing chorus is demanding that executive compensation snared shortly before problems emerged be given back.
articles.abstract: A growing chorus is demanding that executive compensation snared shortly before problems emerged be given back.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHOULD executives get to keep lavish pay packages when the profits that generated their compensation go up in smoke?

articles.headline: Total, the French Oil Company, Places Its Bets Globally
articles.snippet: Total’s experience in Yemen shows how far an oil company will go to unearth new energy supplies.
articles.abstract: Total’s experience in Yemen shows how far an oil company will go to unearth new energy supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen

articles.headline: S.E.C. Chief Pursues Tougher Enforcement
articles.snippet: After years of rejecting an active securities oversight role, the agency is being transformed by Mary L. Schapiro into a watchdog with teeth.
articles.abstract: After years of rejecting an active securities oversight role, the agency is being transformed by Mary L. Schapiro into a watchdog with teeth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than a month after becoming the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mary L. Schapiro is moving swiftly to reverse major decisions by her predecessor and to strengthen an enforcement program that missed several major frauds that cost investors billions of dollars.

articles.headline: Murdoch’s Soft Spot for Print Slows News Corp.
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch’s love of newspapers is weighing on the fortunes of his company, the News Corporation.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s love of newspapers is weighing on the fortunes of his company, the News Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch had an office built for him at The Wall Street Journal within days of buying it 14 months ago, and he has made ample use of it  ordering up a wave of changes in the once-staid paper’s content and culture, from the addition of a weekly sports page to general news displacing financial news on the front page to the thinning of its layers of editing.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: More Money From Fees Gives Banks Good Start
articles.snippet: For all the dire developments among banks, the heavyweights of Wall Street actually had some of their business start off well this year, at least relative to 2008 standards.
articles.abstract: For all the dire developments among banks, the heavyweights of Wall Street actually had some of their business start off well this year, at least relative to 2008 standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial industry has a bit of good news. Really.

articles.headline: Articles on Editor’s Killing Made a Difference
articles.snippet: After Chauncey Bailey, the editor of The Oakland Post, was gunned down 18 months ago, a group of reporters banded together to continue his investigation into a local business.
articles.abstract: After Chauncey Bailey, the editor of The Oakland Post, was gunned down 18 months ago, a group of reporters banded together to continue his investigation into a local business.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Chauncey Bailey, the editor of The Oakland Post, in California, was gunned down in broad daylight on a city street 18 months ago, it was not the end of his journalism. In some ways, it was a new beginning.

articles.headline: U.S. Unit Secretly in Pakistan Lends Ally Support
articles.snippet: American military advisers are working in Pakistan to help its armed forces battle Al Qaeda and the Taliban in lawless tribal areas.
articles.abstract: American military advisers are working in Pakistan to help its armed forces battle Al Qaeda and the Taliban in lawless tribal areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARA, Pakistan  More than 70 United States military advisers and technical specialists are secretly working in Pakistan to help its armed forces battle Al Qaeda and the Taliban in the country’s lawless tribal areas, American military officials said.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: As Doubts Grow, U.S. Will Judge Banks’ Stability
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest banks will face stress tests this week, as the government examines their viability.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest banks will face stress tests this week, as the government examines their viability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration will begin taking a hard look at the financial condition of the country’s 20 biggest banks this week to judge whether they could hold up even if the downturn worsens further than policy makers already expect.

articles.headline: Rift Over Stimulus Embroils G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The Republican response to the economic crisis will shape how the party redefines itself in the wake of recent defeats.
articles.abstract: The Republican response to the economic crisis will shape how the party redefines itself in the wake of recent defeats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican governors split sharply during the weekend over how to respond to the economic crisis, a debate whose outcome will go a long way toward shaping how the national party redefines itself in the wake of its election defeats of recent years.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Iraq’s War Widows Face Dire Need With Little Aid
articles.snippet: The number of war widows has swelled, posing a threat to the country’s tenuous social structures.
articles.abstract: The number of war widows has swelled, posing a threat to the country’s tenuous social structures.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Her twin sisters were killed trying to flee Falluja in 2004. Then her husband was killed by a car bomb in Baghdad just after she had become pregnant. When her own twins were 5 months old, one was killed by an explosive planted in a Baghdad market.

articles.headline: Regulator Faces Fresh Scrutiny Over Trading Inquiry at Lehman
articles.snippet: The ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to brief him on insider-trader accusations presented to the regulator last spring.
articles.abstract: The ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to brief him on insider-trader accusations presented to the regulator last spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission, under fire for failing to heed warnings about the Ponzi scheme that was apparently run by Bernard L. Madoff and lasted for decades, is now under scrutiny for its handling of insider-trading accusations involving former executives at Lehman Brothers.

articles.headline: Philadelphia Newspapers Seeking Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The owners of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News will file for bankruptcy after talks aimed at restructuring company debt broke down, executives said.
articles.abstract: The owners of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News will file for bankruptcy after talks aimed at restructuring company debt broke down, executives said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The owners of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News filed for bankruptcy late Sunday night after talks aimed at restructuring their heavy debt load broke down, executives said.

articles.headline: Stocks Slump on Corporate Woes; Indexes Fall by 3.4%
articles.snippet: Investors pushed the Dow and S.&P. 500 down to 1997 levels as losses piled up in technology and major industrial companies.
articles.abstract: Investors pushed the Dow and S.&P. 500 down to 1997 levels as losses piled up in technology and major industrial companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a day when two leading stock indexes sank to their lowest point in more than a decade, Wall Street did not need the dire problems of banks to lead the way to the bottom.
